headline: CNN NewsNight with Abby Phillip
subHeadline: Harris and Obama Together for First Time on Campaign Trail; 12 Days Out, Harris in Georgia, Trump in Nevada and Arizona; The Double Standard of How Harris and Trump are Judged. "NewsNight State of the Race" Panelists Discuss How V.P. Harris' Town Hall Performance; Beyonce Supports V.P. Harris. Aired 10-11p ET

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And we are lucky tonight to have the host of the Black on Air podcast, Larry Wilmore. He's here in our fifth seat. Let's get right to it. I mean, this was a message that was pretty stark tonight, Larry, from both Kamala Harris and Barack Obama. And it was about an unfettered Donald Trump and the risks. Do you think that's the right message for right now?

utterances.speaker: LARRY WILMORE, WRITER AND COMEDIAN
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, I love that Bruce Springsteen was there, you know, Obama's still trying to prove he was born in the USA, whatever, Obama, you know?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It's never too late.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: It's never too late to win that argument, all right, whatever.But, you know, there's no science around how do you close. You know, that's the thing, you know? And so, to me, the biggest argument against Trump is the whole January 6th argument. I really believe that. If you take politics out of it, you know, get out of your bubble, whatever. His actions on that day on January 6, to me, is disqualifying. You may agree with his policies that like there are so many -- I have never seen so many Republicans who speak out against Trump because of that action alone. And they actually support his policies but they can't vote for him because of that. They may not support Kamala Harris but they're certainly not going to vote for Trump.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I mean, we see it here at this table where many Republicans will come on and they'll say, I don't agree with what he did, I thought it was, you know, deplorable, but I'm still going to vote for him. How does that work? How does that work?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I just want to say that we're going to get into that dynamic on the economic stuff. We've got a couple of economic minds over here at the table. We're going to get into that pretty deeply later into the show. But in the meantime, I mean, it does seem like they are seeing something that tells them we got to hit this hard. Because it's not just the January 6th thing, which is enough for people like Larry, I mean, we have one of his generals coming out saying that he talked about Hitler admiringly, all of these things. Kamala Harris last night on CNN said Donald Trump is a fascist.

utterances.speaker: MARIA CARDONA, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: Yes, and there is a reason for that. And there actually is science around this closing, because data shows, the campaign's data, data that all of the Democratic groups are focusing on, focus groups, all of the things that they're hearing at the doors, I have heard this as well, the January 6th issue is absolutely incredibly compelling and it moves voters.On top of that, the Hitler stuff, the enemy from within, all of the things that are now coming to the fore, not from Kamala Harris' mouth, not from the mouth of any Democrats, from the mouth of non-partisan military decorated generals who worked alongside Donald Trump in national security environments, in the Oval Office, they're the ones who are saying this man is a danger to this country. This man poses a danger to the future of the Constitution, to the future of our democracy. That absolutely moves these independents and the unaffiliated voters that are out there.

utterances.speaker: CATHERINE RAMPELL, CNN ECONOMICS COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: I think it's significant. It's not only the military leaders, which is compelling in and of itself. It's like half of Trump's former cabinet members do not support him.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: Either they have not endorsed him or they have explicitly opposed him. And, you know, he can write it all off as, oh, those are just, you know, disgruntled former employees. This is half of your cabinet.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: His vice president.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: His -- well, he did try to -- he didn't allow people to try to --KEVIN O'LEARY, CHAIRMAN, O'LEARY VENTURES:  The problem with all of this is it's old news. The Jan. 6th deal has been in the market forever. This rhetoric from people saying Trump is a Nazi and a fascist is in the market forever. Do you really want to spend your closing statements on old stuff that's already needled into 45 percent of the country that hates him?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Is it old news or is he also now running to -- I mean the problem, it would be old news if he was not running to be president again.O'LEARY:  Think about what you're trying to replace. You're trying to tell somebody --

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: The Nazi is always relevant, always relevant.O'LEARY:  you should care more about Nazi Trump than the cost of gasoline, your rent, and the protein you buy for your family.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Well, that is literally the --O'LEARY:  And I think that's a losing argument.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: The argument is you should care more about whether the president of the United States is a fascist and admires Nazis than you should about the cost of gasoline.O'LEARY:  Who really believes that?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: You don't think that's fair?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: A lot of Americans believe that.O'LEARY:  I don't think so. I really don't.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: I think the argument is, you should care if he's a Nazi, yes. You should care if he's pro all sorts of other authoritarians, like Viktor Orban and, you know, Putin and various others. That's all relevant. But even if you don't care about those things, even if you're more interested in pocketbook issues, he's still not going to be good for your pocketbook.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: If I could chime in, a lot of this stuff, hell, I've been discussing this for over a year now on this network, the needle hasn't necessarily moved against a former president. I'm just speaking as a strategist here. There's a reason this race is tied neck-and-neck. Now, perhaps some people may dismiss it. Perhaps there are other priorities that people are more concerned about. But, clearly, that message alone isn't resonating with enough voters to give Vice President Harris a comfortable lead in this race to be able to say, I have this in the bag. She does it for a reason.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: See, it's not that message alone. This isn't the only thing that she's talking about. One of the things that I thought was so brilliant last night at the town hall --O'LEARY:  Yes, tell us what she's talking about.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I will tell you what she's talking about.O'LEARY:  Because I don't know. I listened. I couldn't understand anything.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Well, then you're not listening very well.O'LEARY:  I'm trying to.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Last night, what she talked about is that she has a to do list for the American people while Donald Trump has an enemies list.O'LEARY:  What's on the list?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Those are the two things that she is focused on.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: We're going to get to it.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Reducing costs, health care, reproductive rights.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: But last night --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Let me let Larry.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: A lot of it is -- you know, a lot of Americans are, are choosing a leader right now. Kamala Harris didn't have a long runway to prove herself as president, you know? So, what she's really proving to me in these final moments, is she the right leader for America? And many people in the middle are choosing who's going to be the leader. I say Trump disqualifies himself as the leader.Trump is a security risk. You flatter him, he's on your side. He's the craziest security risk ever as far as I'm concerned, as far as for a sitting president. So, people are making decisions, can Kamala lead? Can she lead foreign policy, domestic policy, all these things? Some of those questions, I don't think she's answered. Some of those questions, she may have answered. O'LEARY:  Or can't answer. WILMORE:  Some of those are intangibles too, Kevin. They're not necessarily policy. Some of them are the way she answers questions. Ironically, some of it is the way she may not answer questions. O'LEARY:  I would like to introduce the concept to the panel tonight. It's going to be a short dissertation. But I want you to think about this, because I watched like you did yesterday and something hit me pretty hard. Only 90 days ago, Pelosi went to Biden and said, you need to step aside and convince him to do so. He made the decision, and he did actually ask her, and we've now learned this, is she the right person to drive this home? He questioned that. He could have said, we need to run a process in order for me to make this move, but they decided not to. I don't know who they is. Was it Obama? Was it Pelosi? I don't care who it was. In stock picking, just listen to this analogy, you may agree, you may not, 88 percent of managers, because of the world I live in, cannot beat the S&P year in, year out. So, you give them $1,000, the S&P beats them, they can't pick stocks. This is the second time the Democratic Party has circumvented democracy and chose --

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: That's not true.O'LEARY:  Yes it is. Hillary Clinton was chosen, and she had Bruce Springsteen too. And what happened to her? And now we've chosen --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Kevin, Hillary Clinton won a primary, okay? She won a primary. You may not --O'LEARY:  Nobody could compete with her, even Bernie Sanders.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: She won a primary.O'LEARY:  Okay.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: First of all, that's the first.O'LEARY:  So, did Kamala Harris win the primary?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Listen, we've talked about this before?O'LEARY:  What's wrong with talking about it tonight after what you just saw?

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: Do you think that's really what matters to voters now?O'LEARY:  How many Democrats wish --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Hold on. Hold on a second.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: Let's talk about what matters to voters. Do you really think voters care about the intranescene primary process?O'LEARY:  If you're a Democrat, you sure as hell care today.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I know that you are from Canada, but the primary process -- O'LEARY

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It's not in the Constitution. The political parties can choose however they want to choose their nominee. And as long as they meet the legal deadlines in the states where they are on the ballot, they can do it however they want.O'LEARY:  I just want to be transparent. Yes, I was born in Canada. But just to be transparent, I was born in Canada.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: The Democratic Party process is not democratic.O'LEARY:  No. But my kids were born and raised in Boston, all my investments in the United States. I want the president, whoever it is, to be a winner.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: You're describing something as undemocratic that has absolutely nothing to do with the democratic process,(CROSSTALKS)

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: But I do want to get back to the strategic issues here and the deficits for the vice president, from my position as a Republican strategist. The first question that Anderson Cooper asked Vice President Harris last night was, you've talked a lot about Trump, what message will you give to the American people to convince them that they should vote for you? We've heard everything you said about Trump. The vice president went straight into talking about Donald Trump.There was another gentleman, I think it was the third question, he asked, Well, Vice President Harris, what are you going to do to deal with and address the issues of cost? Now, I know Catherine has her views on that. I understand the limitations of the presidency. But the vice president talked about price gouging and banning that. And Anderson jumped in and he said, well, wait a minute, that's only doing natural disasters. What about beyond that? She did not answer the question. That's still the issue. She's yet to provide sufficient answers. I would argue for many of the questions that some of those swing voters are asking, and that's still -- (CROSSTALKS)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Tonight, the Trump curve, a long running theme of the Trump era that we've been in now for almost a decade, is the different rubrics that have been applied to Donald Trump and basically anyone else who runs against him, including Kamala Harris. Hillary Clinton on CNN just in the last hour, she says that the double standard is very much alive and well.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER DEMOCRATIC PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
utterances.sentences: It still is very difficult to cover Donald Trump. You know, he is incoherent half the time, then he'll come out with something that is about how dangerous migrants are, and that cuts through, and then he goes back to talking about Hannibal Lecter or whatever is on his mind. And it's really hard to cover that.I do think there's a double standard. I think she understands that. She's been underestimated her entire political career. She gets up every day. She puts on those high heels. She goes out there. She makes her case. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I mean, we were just discussing this and I think it's worth being just very clear about it. And we had a whole discussion last time you were on the show about, you know, the -- okay, if we want to talk about policies, what are the policies, right? When you ask Donald Trump that, he doesn't really have an answer, but we want to hear the 15-point plan from Kamala Harris.O'LEARY:  Let's just pick one. Let's pick one.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: No. Before you jump in here, just to be clear, you can't just pick one, right? Like I'm saying to you, if you want a 15-point plan from Kamala Harris, what's the --O'LEARY:  I'm just saying, if we're going to debate policy, let's pick one area and move on.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: No, but the point, the point is that he doesn't actually specify what his policies are.O'LEARY:  Please give me a moment. I think we can focus on one thing. Everybody can agree corporate tax rates are important in the competitiveness of America. Yes, no?

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Yes. O'LEARYNow, does anybody care about that as a policy statement? Has Harris ever explained why it's good to go to 28 percent?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Wait.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: You just lost me. The final voter out in the Midwest trying to make ends meet, you just lost me.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: When did Donald Trump ever say that?O'LEARY:  He's telling you he's not raising corporate taxes.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: He has said that he wants to cut corporate taxes to 15 percent.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes, I get that, but when did he articulate what you just did?

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: Right, exactly.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: That level of specificity.O'LEARY:  He already said that he was going to try and keep his tax policy in place, trying to even reduce to 15 percent.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I think what we're asking here is --O'LEARY:  And why, Abby, we would she care --

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: Maybe in easier way, this is like one of the least popular policies Donald Trump has.O'LEARY:  Which policy?

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure this is it.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Well, if you want to talk about that policy, Kamala Harris talks about how, big corporations should be paying their fair share. That resonates more than everything you just said.O'LEARY:  Where 88 percent -- all your jobs at this table come from the 88 percent job creation is in the private sector.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: When Americans --O'LEARY:  You should care what the tax rates are.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: When Americans are looking at huge corporations who are making money hand over fist while all of the prices at the grocery store are going up, they are going to be looking at what Harris is saying and what Donald Trump is saying. And if Harris is saying, I want these corporations to pay their fair share, to not get out of paying zero --O'LEARY:  That's the reason you want to make America the bottom quartile in the competition?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Let me just pause --O'LEARY:  That's the reason?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: You guys always say that.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Let me just pause this here.(CROSSTALKS) O'LEARY:  You know what I just learned tonight? I have to interview her. I have to do it.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Here's -- the conversation is veered as it often does when we talk about this. This is actually what we're talking about here. You all are having a conversation about policy. The conversation that's happening between Donald Trump and Kamala Harris is not this. Let me just play for you a little bit about of what Donald Trump has been saying. This was at a Turning Point USA event. Just a sliver of what his speeches are like these days.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We can't stand you, you're a shit vice president.She's lazy as hell and she's got that reputation. She's a radical left lunatic. She's not a smart person. She's a low I.Q. individual. She is. She is. She's a low IQ person. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Now, can I? One of the biggest reasons of support of Donald Trump is this, you know, and it is the ideological right against the ideological left. So, a lot of these policy discussions really aren't the reason why people are rushing to the polls. A lot of people who support Trump, I should say, who are in the cult of Trump, cause some people do support him for taxes and those sort of things, but there's a lot of people that support the cult of Trump.He's the cudgel against the left. He's the one that will say she's stupid because she's a leftist, not because she doesn't know policy, you know? And that's what people hear and that's what he's talking to. And when he says that he's never challenged on those he's challenged with regular questions about policy and that, but he's not -- that's not the language he's using to that crowd. He's using a different language.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: Yes. I would also add that if Kamala Harris, you know, started praising Hitler's generals and a famous golfer's genitalia and calling half the country, the enemy of the people, you know, she'd be out of the race. For Trump, it's a Tuesday. And that's how --(CROSSTALKS)

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Because that's why they're supporting him, though. That's the reason.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Any other candidate would not be given a pass for that kind of thing.O'LEARY:  It's only said for eight years. Everybody knows what he said.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: What about the solutions? I mean, I think that's really fundamentally -- if the question is Kamala -- hold on. If the question is, did Kamala Harris explain her tax plan and offer solutions for the border and do all of that in a one hour town hall, I have the same question for Donald Trump. Where are the solutions?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: So, I think most people will say, yes, we should have some level of deportation. You know, we can agree or disagree with that from a policy perspective. I know your thoughts on that, Catherine.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: That's not what he says.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: But he -- he does say that.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: No. He says mass deportation.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, I think on the immigration point, Trump is actually super clear. That might be the one place where he's super, super clear.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: But also on the economic issue, Trump says, look, I want to lower taxes for working class people. Most people will say, okay, that makes sense to me, lower taxes. I don't want to pay more than I have to. That is a very simplistic way to articulate a message that resonates with a lot of people out there. PHILLIP

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Well, that was to Vice President Harris.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Right, exactly. So, that is a very specific policy question. You're saying, Trump is saying, I'm going to lower your taxes. The question is, okay, at what level? Who's getting lower taxes? Now he wants no taxes. Now he wants no taxes on anything.O'LEARY:  He wants to keep the tax where it is now.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: He literally said he's thinking about no income tax at all.O'LEARY:  What I'm finding fascinating about where you're going with this, Abby, is you're saying we don't need details anymore in the last 12 days. It just doesn't matter.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: No, she's saying the literal opposite of that.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: She's saying that if you're going to --O'LEARY:  Let's go to another aspect of policy.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I'm saying the opposite, just to be clear.O'LEARY:  Very popular idea, and I'll give it to Harris, when she came out on price gouging at grocery stores, okay? And she said, look, I'm going to make sure these grocery stores, which, by the way, are the lowest margin of all of our sectors in our economy, 3.5 percent, I'm going to go after them with a new layer of government regulations so that every watermelon you buy is government price tested. Now, that was a very interesting idea. They tried that in the Soviet Union.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: That's not what she said.O'LEARY:  But she can't do it. (CROSSTALKS)

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: It kind of is.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: But that's what she said. She said a national ban on price gouging.(CROSSTALKS)

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: We have a whole, we're going to continue this conversation because I think the other --O'LEARY:  You don't like that one?

utterances.speaker: ABBY PHILLIP, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: It's a political problem that's been around for decades. Is it about the message or the messenger? For Kamala Harris, it seems her salesmanship of popular policies is being weighed and found lacking by voters. That's a central theme of a new and pretty enlightening piece from our very own Catherine Rampell who is here at the table.What is fascinating about that is that this is one of those things where you look at people's views and they're blind on whose name is attached to the views --

utterances.speaker: CATHERINE RAMPELL, CNN ECONOMICS COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: -- and tell us about more what it found.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: So, YouGov, the polling organization, polled Americans on 130 or so policies from both of the candidates and didn't tell the survey respondents whose policies were whose. And they asked people, do you like it, do you dislike it? And the general finding was that Kamala Harris' agenda was head and shoulders much more popular than Trump's. Almost all of her policies got majority support, only about half of Trump's did.And actually, they had done a version of this with YouGov a few months ago where Trump's policies fared even worse. The reason why he's finally above water on about half of his policies is that he's kind of had this recent Panda Peluso where he is giving away tax breaks to everyone and, you know, no tax breaks on social -- no taxes on Social Security benefits or to our tips or what have you. So, Kamala Harris does much better in a blind test than Trump. She does better on almost -- KEVIN O'LEARY, CHAIRMAN, O'LEARY VENTURES:  That is immensely interesting, which tells me she can't articulate.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm getting to that. I'm getting to that, I promise.O'LEARY:  Okay. RAMPELL:   So, we also looked at it by category. So, we looked at it, you know, health care, crime, foreign policy, immigration, et cetera. She bests him on almost every category. There are a couple where they're basically tied -- the economy and immigration, actually. But she even bests him on crime, which I think is super fascinating because if you ask voters in the abstract, who do you trust more on crime? They overwhelmingly say Trump. But then if you look at their policy preferences, again, head and shoulders, Kamala Harris does better, in part because people don't know what all of her policies are.

utterances.speaker: MARIA CARDONA, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST
utterances.sentences: But here's the thing, for the reality.

utterances.speaker: SHERMICHAEL SINGLETON, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR
utterances.sentences: But this way, again, you cannot try to become this new candidate or your authentic self.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: She's not trying to become a new candidate.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: And to Catherine's point, I looked at the data. I was fascinated by the data. But a blind test is not what voters are going to decide when you go into the voting booth. And the reality is what people think and perceive is often their individual and personal reality. So, if they perceive Trump to be better on the economy, better on crime, then that's a net gain potentially for him.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: It could be their individual -- I think that maybe for a lot of voters it is that. But I think there's also a lot of evidence that voters already have preconceived notions about what the political parties are going to do for them. So, a lot of voters believe that Republicans in general are better on the economy. even though there's a lot of evidence that Democratic presidents have been better on job growth and on GDP. And when you ask voters, they'll say, oh, just any Republican is better than a Democrat.O'LEARY:  Fair enough. Let's agree that you're right. Then this goes right to the thesis that they chose the wrong jockey to deliver the mandate.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: No, that's not --O'LEARY:  Because you're basically saying these are the right policies in the wrong jockey's mouth.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: I think that there are a couple of issues here. One is I actually think Kamala Harris has not been the most effective communicator.O'LEARY:  You don't say --

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: -- of her.O'LEARY:  Oh my goodness.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: I think, actually, Republicans have been better at branding her than she has been at branding herself.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Which is a part of the process of electoral politics.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: That's part of the issue. I think the other problem frankly is us, the media, in that policy coverage kind of always gets crowded out of elections in part because horse race coverage is easier, it's more digestible, voters want it. But it's especially hard to get policy coverage in -- in this kind of environment where Trump is on the ballot.O'LEARY:  Last 12 days. Last 12 days.

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: He'll say something crazy and it grows out everything else. That's very true.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: That's very true but here's what I think we're missing even from the polling numbers. And let's remember, Kamala Harris had a very constricted time frame, right? When she came out as the candidate, her-- people liked her, Democrats liked her. Her numbers went up.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's true.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: They skyrocketed. Then she started talking about the policies. If you look at the poll --O'LEARY:  No, no. Then she started talking.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Kevin, let her finish. CARDONA

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Sure. That's all true.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: She's closed the gap on immigration. So, if she wasn't really selling her policies, that wouldn't have been important. The problem is I don't think that there has been time enough to close the gap where everyone is like, why hasn't she put this away?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Let me add one more data point here. Because I think that you're making an important point that if this were all just about how terrible the economy is and how bad, Kamala Harris' policies are, then I don't think you'd be seeing this in terms of what the Republican Party and Trump's allies are doing in terms of spending.In their spending, which is they're putting their money where their mouth is, right? They're spending more now than in September on LGBTQ rights. They're spending less on the economy. They're spending less on inflation. Taxation is the only thing that's going up because it's going from zero to now closer to 40 percent. So, I don't know. I mean, you're a business guy. If they're not putting their money behind an economic message, what does that tell you?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yes.O'LEARY:  I think the case I'm trying to make to all of you and I hope I'm going to win it by the end of this show, is that there's nothing wrong with the policies or whatever they are. This is the same candidate that lost in 2019 and 2020 and has never been tested by the markets for various reasons we can argue about, but she's never won anything. And if she loses, I'm not saying she will --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: She has won a Senate seat, just to be clear.O'LEARY:  Okay, great, but we're now talking about the presidency here, all right?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: And vice president.O'LEARY:  If she happens to lose, I think the soul-searching will be -- picked the wrong horse.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Joe Biden -- Joe Biden flamed out in the primaries with Hillary and Obama. He did not win one primary, nothing. And then he became vice president and then won the presidency.O'LEARY:  Well, thanks to South Carolina.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Maybe she'll have a unique set of circumstances.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: And if you want to look at winners and losers, Donald Trump lost in 2020. The only election he has won is in 2016. He lost 2018, he lost 2020, he lost 2022.O'LEARY:  Okay, make it simple. How did she do last night? How did she do last night?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I thought she did absolutely --O'LEARY:   She was great, right?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: She was good. I thought she was good. I know a lot of people -- O'LEARY

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Let me talk.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: She's okay. She's all right.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I thought she was fine.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: All right, let me do a quick survey just because I feel like everybody's not - one word.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: In one word, how did she do last night?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Not good.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I thought she was good.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: She was all right.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Fine.O'LEARY:  Horrific. Horrific.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: All right. Now, we know.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: But the third was shaky, Maria.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: I'll tell you what the problem is.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: She was shaky.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Kamala is using two methods, politically, Abby.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: She convinced undecided voters. Yes or no?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: She convinced two out of the five.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: She convinced undecided voters.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Okay, sure. Two out of the five.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Okay. None of them went for Trump. None of them were leaning towards Trump.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETION
utterances.sentences: But Maria, if they're not voting for her, well, that's not a net positive. You know that.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: You guys are saying that she's not closing the deal, and she actually is. WILMORE

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: There's nothing wrong with that. I think the audience would appreciate that more if you gave a real valuable answer as to why you changed your mind, that fits your thesis of why you don't want to do that. Just be straightforward. But you don't have to -- you don't have to be so forceful in a non-answer. And I think that can put in --

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: So, actually, fracking is a very good example of what I was talking about, people not knowing what her policies are. We've been talking about people like her policies or not, and we haven't actually talked about what the policies are, which is a microcosm of this whole problem. But one of the things that you have pulled about was support for increasing domestic oil and gas production, which actually both candidates support.They are both vociferously on record supporting that. And most voters think only Trump stands for it. And it's partly because you don't get clear answers from Kamala Harris about why it is her positions changed and what she stands for today.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: And a good vice president if she said, you know, I changed my mind on this. Well, I thought cracking was horrible, so --

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: And a good way for her to say that, I mean, like she might have been trying to get away if I'm advising the vice president. and we know this question's going to come up. I had a previous position when I ran before. I've been vice president for three and a half years.When you're a vice president, you have access to a ton of information. Your minds change. I understand the importance of energy independence. Therefore, I'm supporting fracking. Most people say, well, hell, that makes a lot of sense. But she's not saying that.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Obama did this with gay marriage.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: That's not what she's saying.

utterances.speaker: WLMORE
utterances.sentences: He said he evolved in gay marriage. Mitt Romney couldn't say that because Republicans don't believe in evolution.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's not true, Larry. That is not true, Larry.O'LEARY:  Just listen to yourselves right now. Twelve nights to go.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Oh, I know that, Kevin.O'LEARY:  And you're trying to explain to this candidate how to answer a question, and she is the candidate for President of the United States?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I'm not trying to explain to her. He is.O'LEARY:  Come on.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: That just settles it right there. But my point, though, Kevin, is as a strategist, as I'm looking at this and I'm looking at the deficits or some of the issues with the vice president and her inability to communicate in a concise way, her policy changes, she's failing on that.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: No, but see, this is what we really do. She's failing on that.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: We really do have to go. We really do have to go, guys.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: There's a lot of information.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Double standard, what you're talking about.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Everyone, stand by for me.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: It's not a double standard. It's not.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Tonight, a headline from "The Wall Street Journal" that Elon Musk certainly will not like. The paper is reporting that Musk and Russian President Vladimir Putin have been in regular contact since 2022. Putin, according to the journal's sources, at one point even asked Musk to not activate his Starlink satellite internet service over Taiwan as a favor to fellow autocrat Xi Jinping of China.Now, Musk didn't reply to the journal's ask for comment and the Pentagon didn't comment, as well. Kremlin did acknowledge one phone call but said that the pair are not in regular contact. CNN has not been able to independently verify any of this reporting as of this hour, but this is a pretty big deal considering all the things about Elon Musk.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: And especially concerning, like you said, Elon Musk has kind of become one of Donald Trump's biggest advisors. He's out there possibly doing something illegal already with trying to buy votes and the whole deal.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: He's handing out million-dollar checks.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Questionably.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: The lotteries, exactly. The DOJ, Department of Justice, has said, warned him this could possibly be illegal. I think we don't know what the details are, right? The U.S. officials don't really know. But it's certainly not something that our national security officials are going to think that is a good thing.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, even to take, let's take Trump and their relationship out of it for just a second. Elon Musk has a $1.8 billion classified contract with the United States government. And it raises a lot of big questions about what are we doing here? I mean, are we just --O'LEARY:  We're working with the world's greatest --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: No, no, but I'm just wondering, I mean, if you have, you know, too much credit card debt, you can't get a security clearance.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: I mean, he is the world's greatest -- I don't disagree with that.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: What are we doing here?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: You know what? There's just nothing to argue about.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know about that. I have a lot of issues with someone that we're relying on for very sensitive information and technological advancements, working with Vladimir Putin, potentially working at the behest of Xi Jinping. These are two of our greatest adversaries. I got a big issue with that.And if this reporting is true, then we may need to reconsider some of these engagements that the federal government is having with Elon Musk. I love Elon Musk. I think he's a brilliant guy. But this crap is not okay for a whole host of reasons. These countries are our adversaries. Their objective in every regard is to defeat the United States however possible. And so, this does make me very, very nervous. O'LEARY:  I read that news a different way.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: I don't know about that, Kevin.O'LEARY:  Basically, the Supreme Leader of China saying do not put that freedom of speech over Taiwan. I forbid you to do it.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: They have no right to forbid that.O'LEARY:  Wait, wait, wait.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: This is an American company, Kevin. What are we talking about, Kevin?O'LEARY:  Just like he did over Ukraine, gave him the finger. Said, I'm going to do whatever I want. I'm Elon Musk. And that's exactly what happened.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Oh, Kevin.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I don't know that that's what -- that's not what I -- just to be clear.O'LEARY:  That's my interpretation.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: The reporting doesn't actually say what he did in response to that request.O'LEARY: We're speculating. I'm speculating.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: So, I mean, you can speculate, but that's not what the reporting says.O'LEARY:  It said he -- at the insistence of the Supreme Leader of China.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: He was asked to do it. It doesn't say --O'LEARY:  I hope he didn't do it. He obviously wouldn't do it. He was Starlink above it.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: But the issue is also that, I mean, when you talk about Starlink, Elon has gone back and forth about whether he's going to provide Starlink to Ukraine. He started off trying to support Ukraine in this war.O'LEARY:  He did.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: And then he pulled back at several really important junctures.O'LEARY:  It's working tonight.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: That is not speculation. That's proven.O'LEARY:  I know, but it's working tonight.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I think one of the things that is also very concerning is it reminds people about the links between Donald Trump and Putin. And the fact that Donald Trump admires Putin, you know, treats him as like one of his best friends along with other strongmen around the world.And I think it really feeds into the message, one of the closing messages of the Kamala Harris campaign, that this is not somebody, Donald Trump is not somebody, as Elon Musk is his closest advisor, not somebody that we can trust to be commander in chief. O'LEARY:  Shouldn't you treat your adversaries closer?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: But our adversaries should not have, in my personal opinion, that potential level of influence over an American CEO of a very important company because of the technology that we have. We should investigate.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Well, and they're already in a relationship, which he should be careful about because he's going to make Trump jealous, you know, as much as Trump loves Putin. In fact, I mean, this is really bad news for Trump. If he's having -- it's like Putin's a teenager. What are all these secret conversations he's having?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I know. How does he have time?

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: On the phone. Exactly.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Who even talks on the phone anymore?

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: On his bed, talking on the phone.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: With Trump?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yes.O'LEARY:   Every leader wants the opportunity including the President of France during the Olympics, sat him right beside him at the state dinner. I mean, he's Elon Musk, he's Batman.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Look, Kevin, again, I get your point about where Elon Musk is because of everything he's created, everything he's led.O'LEARY:  Can you translate for China for me on that one?

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: But if Vladimir Putin is calling me, I'm not answering Vladimir Putin's phone.O'LEARY:  You realize he makes cars in China.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: I'm not answering the phone call of Xi Jinping. I'm an American. My interest is about America first.O'LEARY:  Wait a second. He makes cars in China. No, no. He makes Teslas in China.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: But he also has federal-confident top secret, above top secret knowledge that --

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Kevin, do you acknowledge that Putin and Russia right now and for some time, their adversaries?O'LEARY:  Hundred percent. I'm the guy that wants to put 400 percent tax on China.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I think that's Shermichael's --O'LEARY:  You do.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: No, I'm talking about Russia. But Shermichael's point is that because it's Russia, it's different.O'LEARY:  But you've all of a sudden made the assumption he's done something wrong. SINGLETON:  No, no, that's not what I'm saying, Kevin. I'm simply saying I wouldn't even answer or take a call from the leaders of either of those two countries. O'LEARY:  Wait a second.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: I just would not.O'LEARY:  You're making cars in China and the Supreme Leader calls you and you're not going to take his call?

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: We're talking about Putin.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: We're talking about different things here.O'LEARY:  You just said both countries.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Okay, so China, what is Xi Jinping calling Elon Musk about? Let's go with that hypothetical.O'LEARY:  He's got $50 billion invested there.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: So, what does he want to say?O'LEARY:  He may say that he's going to change my policy.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Then change your damn policy. That's the end of the conversation.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: And that's not normally something--

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: There's no need for Vladimir Putin to be calling Elon Musk.O'LEARY:  You just want to keep your adversaries closer to you so you have information.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: That's the government's job, Kevin. Not Elon Musk's position or job.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: All right, guys, we got to leave it there.O'LEARY:  He did go visit him to get that plant.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: We're back and it's time for a special news nightcap. Larry Wilmore, you have 30 seconds to say your piece. WILMOREarisen for the Arnold Palmer estate. Everything from enhanced drugs, to energy drinks, to scented candles are now on the table, and they're all possible because of Trump's comment about Arnold Palmer. And I mean, one of the slogans is to say, hey, whether you want to drive it long or just keep it on the sharp, go ahead. You know, I feel like I'm on the sharp take right now. Teed up at the king. O'LEARY:  I got to tell you, do not give up your day job. I would say that right now.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: You're my biggest fan.O'LEARY:  Biggest fan.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Mr. Wonderful, would you invest?O'LEARY:  No.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Wait, what are you talking about?O'LEARY: The guy's dead.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Yes, but we used the name, you know.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: Rigor mortis? You can license it, Kevin. You can license it, the name. There you go.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I thought you were going to say that the estate would sue Trump and then.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Oh, no, no, that's too conventional.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Use that.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Marketing opportunities.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: He has given a whole new name --

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: You're thinking like an entrepreneur. I like it.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: I think women are going to think twice about ordering an Almond Palmer.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Okay, real quick guys.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Or it becomes a more popular drink, I'm saying.

utterances.speaker: SINGLETON
utterances.sentences: I think more popular.

utterances.speaker: WILMORE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Real quick, I mean we have like 30 seconds. But Beyonce is finally coming.

utterances.speaker: CARDONA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Tomorrow, finally.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I'm curious about what she's going to say to be honest, because we don't hear from Beyonce.O'LEARY: So dumb to back a politician and lose half your audience. So dumb. Either politician.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I don't know. Who do you think her audience is?

utterances.speaker: RAMPELL
utterances.sentences: Exactly.O'LEARY:  Half her audience. No Republicans listen to her?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I don't say no Republicans, but if you are a Republican and you listen to her, you know what you're getting from --O'LEARY:  If you're an artist, and I was your manager, I would forbid you from endorsing --
